ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to apply geological concepts to actual rock and actual landscapes. I learned how to identify rock types and characteristics.
this lab was really fun if you were able to understand the content. the field trips were always nice, and I was able to develop some vocabulary and skills used in the geology world.
This was a great lab addition to EPS 110, where we learned about the course content in a more in-depth, hands-on way.
I learned some basic mineral identification and about the geology of the state of Connecticut.
ROCKSROCKSROCKSROCKS- kidding. This class is just a wonderful place for geokids to gather and appreciate all the department has to offer.
How to describe and identify rocks, the geologic history of the area and of the Appalachian mountains, and how to perform certain field work methods.
field observations etc

Learned how to analyze outcrops out in nature.
Learned how to examine rocks and identify most of the minerals and intricacies within them.
Basic steps of becoming a field geologist.

I gained a hands-on understanding of general geology. I learned about the tectonic history of New England and became much more adept at identifying rocks and minerals. This class changed how I think about the geological world around me, that is to say, the world, in the most literal sense. Dynamic Earth lab allowed me to take the concepts I learned in the lecture course and apply them to real-world examples, particularly during field trips, which provided an invaluable chance to cement the concepts in my brain and allowed for a corporeal understanding that will stick with me, I think, for as long as I live.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The major strength is the fall break trip! It was so much fun and I really feel like I learned things about geology I couldn't have learned from New Haven. Other field trips and hands-on activities were great, and Professor Evans is incredible. I think a little more instruction in the actual lab would have been helpful, especially with respect to things like identifying rock types.
This course was fun, and the field trips were interesting and not too cumbersome.

Strengths: I really loved the structure of this class, with every-other-Friday labs and awesome field trips. The teaching team is very knowledgeable and I found I learned the most by asking questions (or listening to the answers to other students' questions!). 
Weaknesses: For new topics introduced in lab, it would be very helpful to be given information as a guide and then be asked to apply this knowledge in order to build a strong foundation. For example, I think it would be more effective to be told about mineral properties and then asked to identify minerals rather than to fill in a chart of mineral properties with information we found from the internet which may not have been complete. Similarly, I think it would be more effective to be taught about the rock formations we saw on field trips and then asked to apply this knowledge rather than to guess based on little background information. I thought some labs (e.g., the cemetery hunt) were better at this than others (e.g., mineral identification around campus). Hope this makes sense!
Pretty great. Plz make sure both cabins are heated next year on the trip though. We in the little cabin had no idea that the big one had heat.

Strengths were that lessons were engaging and often required hands-on or out of the classroom exploratory work that was interesting and furthered learning. Weaknesses were that some exercises were difficult and confusing for beginners and required more prior knowledge than what was covered in the course material.
Field trips are great
strengths: field trips and labs were fun and low workload, oct break field trip was very fun

Strengths: the passion of the professor and the TA, the field trips, being able to handle rock specimen of all different kinds

Weaknesses: the October field trip does indeed take your time away from studying if you need to do so ( I didnt but this may be a concern for others), I felt the explanation of the science behind some things we saw on the field were a bit complicated and hard to digest for people new to geology

Hands down, the greatest strength of this class is in the fieldwork. There is simply no substitute for hands-on learning in real geologic environments. The field trips are well thought out and very cogently illustrate pertinent geological concepts. Not to mention, they are really fun (especially the Fall Break trip)! I truly don't know if I can think of any real weaknesses in this course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely!!! Prof Evans makes geology so fun and this class will change how you view geology and rocks.
yes if you take the class at the same time it'll be much easier. just prepared to not know a lot of the material.
Yes, if you are taking EPS 110 and looking for a 0.5 credit class, you can't go wrong.
Yes! A very fun class to get exposure to geology up close.

If you are interested in geology, take this lab! I will say that there is a wide range in student experience and skill levels. Students who are EPS majors and seem to be able to identify every mineral first try are mixed in with those who have never taken a geology course before and are just looking to learn, which can make the course challenging for the latter group. That being said, if you come in with an open mind and ask a lot of questions, you will have fun either way!
I think if you are not a geology major it will be a lot harder for you to appreciate this class especially with so many excited geology kids. But all geology kids should take this class.
Yes, it's a fun and interesting course that gets you outdoors and looking at rocks in the field.
Absolutely, great class
definitely recommend for the field trips!

Absolutely. You get to build a relationship with the prof and TA through these field trips. Being able to look at stuff of the earth we rely on and learn about how everything came to be is truly fascinating

I would absolutely recommend this lab to anyone interested in learning more about geology. Dynamic Earth Lab has beautifully shaped my understanding of geology and geological processes. After this course (in concert with the lecture course), I walk outside and am confronted by a wealth of astounding geological truths that I had never before noticed or cared about. I truly see the world in a novel way now, and I will be continuing my exploration of geology in part due to the seed of curiosity and fascination that this course has sowed in me. If this sounds like something you want to experience, take the course! Engage with it! And, afterward, using the knowledge you gain, continue to wander, wonder, and reason about the beautiful world we find ourselves a part of!
I would recommend this to anyone who wants an even more in-depth understanding of the material taught in EPS 110. The field trips make the class more enriching and fun!
